On Fri, 10 Dec 2004 21:21:37 -0000, Kenneth Stanley
<kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> This sounds like a good idea.  I will keep it in mind.  You know,
> ultimately what we are up against is just the fact that no sample
> can be guaranteed to perfectly represent its generating distribution.
> It's likely there will always be extraordinary situations that were
> not encountered in whatever training set was experienced during
> evolution.  At the same time, that doesn't mean we can't do better,
> it just means reaching exactly 100% of all possible test cases is
> unlikely for complicated problems or domains.

That's a good point.

We have a couple of particular problems presented by the fingerprint
classification domain that bear on this.  One are fingerprints that
are not completely one class.  That is, they are somewhat an arch and
somewhat a left loop.

The other is rejects.  Some images are of such poor quality, and
contain so much noise, that it is inherently difficult to get enough
information to make a classification.

So it's virtually impossible to evolve networks that have seen cases
that not only cover all the variation in a particular class, but those
fuzzy cases that are blends of classes, plus the full range of
degraded fingerprint images that contain all sorts of different noise.

Derek
